title: Van Gogh's Journey
subtitle: Follow in the footsteps of Vincent van Gogh across Europe
introduction: Vincent van Gogh's short but intense artistic life took him from the Netherlands through Belgium and France. In just 10 years, he created over 900 paintings, many inspired by the specific places he lived. Today, you can follow his journey and see where masterpieces like Starry Night, Sunflowers, and Cafe Terrace at Night were created.

trail.description: Vincent Willem van Gogh was born on March 30, 1853, in this small village in the southern Netherlands. His father was a Protestant minister. The family home no longer exists, but a reconstruction stands on the original site.
trail.significance: Birthplace and childhood home. Vincent's early exposure to the Dutch countryside would influence his later landscape paintings.

whatToSee.name: Van Gogh House (Reconstruction)
whatToSee.description: Reconstruction of Van Gogh's birthplace with exhibitions about his early life

whatToSee.name: Van Gogh Church
whatToSee.description: The Protestant church where Vincent's father preached

trail.shortDescription: Where Vincent worked as an art dealer and began drawing seriously
trail.description: Vincent first came to The Hague at 16 to work for Goupil & Cie, an art dealership. He returned years later to study art seriously, living with a woman named Sien and her children while developing his drawing skills.
trail.significance: Vincent's first exposure to the art world as a dealer. His second stay marked his serious commitment to becoming an artist.

whatToSee.name: Mauritshuis
whatToSee.description: Houses works by Vermeer and Rembrandt that influenced Vincent

whatToSee.name: Former Goupil & Cie Location
whatToSee.description: Where teenage Vincent worked as an art dealer

trail.shortDescription: Where Vincent discovered Impressionism and transformed his style
trail.description: Vincent moved to Paris to live with his brother Theo, an art dealer. Here he encountered Impressionism for the first time, met Toulouse-Lautrec, Gauguin, and Pissarro, and his palette transformed from dark Dutch tones to vibrant colors.
trail.significance: A pivotal transformation. Vincent created over 200 paintings here and developed the bold, colorful style we know today.

whatToSee.name: Musee d'Orsay
whatToSee.description: Houses several Van Gogh paintings from this period

whatToSee.name: Montmartre
whatToSee.description: Where Vincent lived with Theo and painted the windmills and cabarets

whatToSee.name: 54 Rue Lepic
whatToSee.description: The apartment building where Vincent and Theo lived (plaque on building)

whatToSee.name: Le Moulin de la Galette
whatToSee.description: The windmill Vincent painted multiple times, still standing

trail.shortDescription: Vincent's most prolific period. Sunflowers, Yellow House, Cafe Terrace
trail.description: Seeking stronger light and color, Vincent moved south to Arles in February 1888. In just 15 months, he created over 300 paintings including some of his most famous works. He rented the Yellow House, dreaming of an artists' colony. Paul Gauguin's visit ended with Vincent's mental breakdown and the infamous ear incident.
trail.significance: His most prolific and iconic period. The Sunflowers, Cafe Terrace at Night, The Bedroom, and The Yellow House were all painted here.

whatToSee.name: Fondation Vincent van Gogh
whatToSee.description: Contemporary art museum dedicated to Van Gogh's legacy in Arles

whatToSee.name: Cafe Van Gogh (Cafe Terrace)
whatToSee.description: The actual cafe from Cafe Terrace at Night. Still operating, painted yellow
whatToSee.note: The cafe still looks remarkably like the painting. Best visited at night.

whatToSee.name: Yellow House Site
whatToSee.description: The Yellow House was destroyed in WWII, but a plaque marks the location

whatToSee.name: Arles Hospital
whatToSee.description: Where Vincent was treated after cutting his ear. The courtyard garden he painted is preserved.

whatToSee.name: Langlois Bridge
whatToSee.description: A reconstruction of the drawbridge Vincent painted multiple times

trail.artworksNote: Sadly, no original Van Gogh paintings remain in Arles. They are spread across museums worldwide.

trail.shortDescription: The asylum where Vincent painted Starry Night
trail.description: After his breakdown in Arles, Vincent voluntarily admitted himself to the Saint-Paul-de-Mausole asylum. Despite his mental struggles, he created 150 paintings here including The Starry Night, his most famous work. He painted the view from his window, the asylum garden, and the surrounding olive groves.
trail.significance: Created The Starry Night and some of his most emotionally intense works. A period of incredible productivity despite severe mental illness.

whatToSee.name: Saint-Paul-de-Mausole
whatToSee.description: The asylum where Vincent stayed. His room is recreated, and you can see the exact view he painted in Starry Night.
whatToSee.note: The monastery is still a psychiatric facility, with part open as a museum.

whatToSee.name: Van Gogh Walking Trail
whatToSee.description: Self-guided walk through Saint-Remy with 21 stops showing reproductions of Van Gogh's paintings at the locations where they were painted.

trail.shortDescription: Vincent's final 70 days and resting place
trail.description: Vincent spent his final 70 days in this village north of Paris, under the care of Dr. Gachet. Despite his deteriorating mental state, he painted at a furious pace, roughly one painting per day, creating 80 works including Wheatfield with Crows and Church at Auvers. On July 27, 1890, he shot himself in a wheat field and died two days later. He is buried here alongside his brother Theo.
trail.significance: His final and most poignant chapter. The church, wheat fields, and Dr. Gachet's house remain much as Vincent painted them.

whatToSee.name: Auberge Ravoux
whatToSee.description: The inn where Vincent rented a tiny attic room for 3.50 francs a day. The room where he died is preserved exactly as it was.
whatToSee.note: The room is tiny and deeply moving. Advance booking recommended.

whatToSee.name: Church at Auvers
whatToSee.description: The church Vincent painted, instantly recognizable. The painting is at the Musee d'Orsay; the church looks nearly identical today.

whatToSee.name: Van Gogh's Grave
whatToSee.description: Vincent and Theo are buried side by side. The graves are covered with ivy, as Vincent often painted.

whatToSee.name: Wheat Fields
whatToSee.description: The fields above the town where Vincent painted his final works and where he shot himself. Walking trails available.

whatToSee.name: Dr. Gachet's House
whatToSee.description: Home of the doctor who cared for Vincent. Now a museum.
whatToSee.note: Limited opening hours, check before visiting.

currentLocations.title: Where to See Van Gogh's Work Today
currentLocations.description: Van Gogh's 900+ paintings are now spread across the world. Here are the top museums:

topMuseums.name: Van Gogh Museum
topMuseums.note: The world's largest Van Gogh collection

topMuseums.name: Kroller-Muller Museum
topMuseums.note: Second largest collection, in a beautiful sculpture garden

suggestedItineraries.name: Dutch Origins
suggestedItineraries.description: Explore Van Gogh's birthplace and the world's best collection of his work

suggestedItineraries.name: Provence Trail
suggestedItineraries.description: Follow Van Gogh through the south of France where he created his most famous works

suggestedItineraries.name: The Complete Journey
suggestedItineraries.description: A comprehensive trip through Van Gogh's entire life journey

timeline.event: Begins work at Goupil & Cie art dealers, The Hague
Decides to become an artist at age 27
Arrives in Arles, begins most prolific period
Gauguin visits; Vincent cuts his ear
Enters Saint-Paul-de-Mausole asylum; paints Starry Night
